Authors:
Shaoying Liu, Chengran Zhou, Tao Wan, Guanliang Meng,
Robert W. Murphy, Zhengxin Fan, Mingkun Tang, Yang Liu, Tao Zeng, Shunde
Chen, Yun Zhao, Shanlin Liu
Title:
Out of the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau and get flourishing - the
evolution of Neodon voles (Rodentia: Cricetidae) revealed by systematic
sampling and low coverage whole genome sequencing
Keywords:
Neodon evolution, speciation, Qinghai-Xizang Plateau,
Time-calibrated genomic analysis, Geometric morphological analysis, sky
island effects.
Abstract:
Neodon, genus of a short time evolutionary history, was
reported to be diverged from its relatives in early stage of Pleistocene
associated with the uplift of Himalayan Mountains. Only 4 species were
well documented in Neodon for a long period of time until last years
when a systematic work described and added three new species, adjusted
three species used to belong to Lasiopodomys, Phaiomys, Microtus to
Neodon and removed one species (Neodon juldaschi) to genus Blanfordimys,
leading to a total of eight species recorded in Neodon. To gain a better
insight into the phylogeny and ecology of Neodon, we have systematically
sampled Neodon species along the whole Hengduan and Himalayan Mountains
in the last 15 years. In addition to morphological identification, we
generated 1x - 15x whole genome sequencing (WGS) data and achieved the
mitochondrial genomes and an average of 5,382 nuclear genes for each
morpho-species. Both morphology and phylogeny results supported an extra
six new species in Neodon (nominated Neodon shergylaensis sp. nov., N.
namchabarwaensis sp. nov., N. liaoruii sp. nov., N. chayuensis sp. nov.,
N. bomiensis sp. nov., and N. bershulaensis sp. nov.). This is the first
study that included Neodon samples covering its entire distribution area
in China and this systematic sampling also revealed a long-time
underestimation of NeodonÂ’s diversity, and suggested its speciation
events were highly linked to the Qinghai-Xizang Plateau uplift events.
The results also revealed that Qinghai-Xizang Plateau is the center of
origin and evolution of Neodon, and the impetus of speciation include
climate change, isolation of rivers and mountains.
